One way to dedicate yourself is by taking the time to invest in the goal. This is more than writing down the goal as you might write down, “Buy milk,” on a to-do-list. That is not a deep investment, only taking a few seconds of your time to write, “I want to be healthy” or “I want to finish a marathon”. Instead, invest the time to formally structure the goal. One way to do this is by using the S.M.A.R.T. model. Using the model requires you invest some effort in your goal, providing a structure that includes actions you need to take, how success will be measured, etc. When you dedicate some time structuring the goal, it will help you become more invested as well as provide clarity. Below is one version of the model. It is geared towards developing multiple structured goals verses some formats of S.M.A.R.T. or in some versions S.M.A.R.T.E.R., that tend to focus on a single goal. Find a version that works for you.

Make sure it is clearly defined. If your goal is not clear or not specific enough to fit your goals it will make it much more difficult to accomplish those goals.Make sure it is realistic. If your goals is outlandish and unrealistic, that will also certainly hinder your chances of achieving that goal. Make sure your goal is realistic. You can surely elaborate on it or make a bigger goal later, but make sure your goal is attainable.Make sure you have what you need. So many time I make big goals that really challenge myself but I don’t even have what is necessary to complete those goals. Make sure you have the tools (i.e., the money, the time, the space, etc) or whatever is necessary for you to achieve it.Make sure it is a challenge. If your goal is too small or boring chasing the goal for you will become just a boring exercise. You need to make sure you push your limits.

In his book " The Success Principles: How to Get from Where You Are to Where You Want to Be ", Jack Canfield tells a compelling story. As the story goes, Bruce Jenner, famed U.S. Decathlete and Olympic gold medalist, was speaking to a roomful of Olympic hopefuls. He asked the group if they had made a list of their goals, and all hands went up. This isn't surprising considering the fact that Olympians are always focused, dedicated and ambitious overachievers. Then, came Bruce's follow-up question: “How many of you have your list of goals with you right now?” Only one hand went up. Of all the top athletes in that room, only Dan O'Brien carried his goals with him. So, he could always read them and stay focused on them. Not surprisingly, Dan O'Brien went on to achieve a huge goal when he won gold in the decathlon at the 1996 Olympics. In short, set goals, write it down and then carry it with you everywhere you go.

How will we achieve when we have no experience of achievement. Visualization will create that experience. The mind will believe because it knows that the goal was attainable. So then it will become reality. Our belief systems built up with what we have been told has flaws. Use common sense. If you make a goal with all the effort you will be committed to it. If the time comes for hard work then you will do it. These are actionable things to do not talk about. The Power Of Creative Visualization: Unleash The Power Within You

How to achieve a goal? Simple. Work towards it consistently. I have a confession. I'm fat. And it is my goal since years to be fit and muscular. I have tried diets and exercises for the same. But did it work? No. I'm still fat. Why? Because I wasn't consistent. I would stop excercising when I felt bored or over ate at a party. So the problem was not that I didn't have a goal. It wasn't that I didn't write down the goals, but the lack of consistency. So how do you achieve your goal? By working towards it consistently. Not a day, not a week, but always. Always. Success isn't an end point, but the joint result of consistent small actions
